Ayşe holds a Master’s degree in Marketing Communications from the University of Westminster and a BA in Business Administration from Istanbul University. She has 15 years of experience in branding, retail start-up strategy, retail management, brand management and retail marketing. She is currently the Marketing Team Leader for Caffè Nero Turkey and has previously worked for major international brands such as Topshop and The Body Shop. View the Ayse AKBAL - UK Adventure video from British Council Turkey on Vimeo . The Department of Politics and International Relations at University of Westminster has continued to grow its partnership with Koceali University in Izmit, Turkey, with a student exchange and field trip held in May each year. Title: South Africa | University of Westminster, London
Info: Studying at the University of Westminster, you'll be in the heart of London – with all the opportunities the city has to offer on your doorstep. Our students join us from over 160 nations and we boast a worldwide alumni community to join when you graduate. For more information on what London and the University of Westminster can offer you, have a look at our Student life pages . The University of Westminster’s Africa Media Centre promotes collaborative research on African film, media, communication and social change, and often hosts conferences and guest lectures in London. Most recently, Westminster academics from the Faculty of Architecture and the Built Environment were awarded a major £500k grant for an urban transformation project in South Africa. The project aims to develop and test an environmental and construction management toolkit, helping local communities in informal settlements in South Africa to be self-reliant and resilient over the long-term future. Entry requirements Undergraduate Postgraduate Applying for a course If you are interested in studying for a Bachelor's degree (eg a BA, BSc, BEng or LLB) at the University of Westminster, you will need to check that you meet our entry requirements. We have included typical entry requirements below, but these are simply a guideline. Some courses may also have specific subject or grade requirements, which will be listed on individual course pages. You will typically need to have one of the following: National Senior Certificate (with matriculation) with grades 66655. Some disciplines will require higher grades, such as Law, Media Studies and Architecture Senior Certificate (with matriculation endorsement) with at least BBBCC A recognised International Foundation course from a UK institution. You will typically need to have one of the following: Bachelor's (Honours) degree with a minimum of 60% from a recognised South African institution. Students applying for postgraduate courses requiring a UK Second Class Upper degree will need 70-74%, and those applying for a course requiring a UK First Class degree will need a 75-100%. Professional Bachelor's degree Additionally, considerations may be made for those applicants with the following: High grades from a Bachelor's degree followed by a Master's degree. Title: Lithuania | University of Westminster, London

As an alternative to a full degree, have a look at our various study abroad programmes , where you can spend a summer, semester or year with us in London. Online open days Join us at an online open day and get a feel for student life at the University of Westminster. You'll get a chance to: Speak to our academic staff Ask us any questions you may have about student finance and accommodation Find an online open day Events in your country At present, there are no planned events in your country. Please check back at a later date or explore our online open days or information sessions . Overseas representatives The University of Westminster's representatives in Lithuania can help you with all stages of the admissions process. Our representatives are: Kalba W: kalba.lt Study Plan International Ltd W: studyplan.lt If you wish to raise anything about the services provided by our representatives, you can contact us at [email protected] . International student blog If you have ever wondered what it’s like to study in London and at the University of Westminster, our international bloggers will be able to help. Our international students are sharing their experiences of adapting to life in the UK, making new friends for life, dealing with homesickness and fulfilling their dreams. Url: https://www.westminster.ac.uk/international/your-country/luxembourg
Title: Luxembourg | University of Westminster, London
Info: Studying at the University of Westminster, you'll be in the heart of London – with all the opportunities the city has to offer on your doorstep. Our students join us from over 160 nations and we boast a worldwide alumni community to join when you graduate. For more information on what London and the University of Westminster can offer you, have a look at our Student life pages . Keep in mind that a postgraduate loan is now available to all UK/EU students to help pay for Master’s courses. For details, have a look at our EU, EEA and Swiss students funding page . As an alternative to a full degree, have a look at our various study abroad programmes , where you can spend a summer, semester or year with us in London. Entry requirements Undergraduate Postgraduate Applying for a course If you are interested in studying for a Bachelor's degree (eg a BA, BSc, BEng or LLB) at the University of Westminster, you will need to check that you meet our entry requirements. We have included typical entry requirements below, but these are simply a guideline. Some courses may also have specific subject or grade requirements, which will be listed on individual course pages. You will typically need to have te following: Diplôme de Fin d'Etudes secondaires or Diplôme de Fin d'Etudes secondaires Techniques with an overall score 36 (Mention assez bien) For more details on the application process, visit our How to apply page Go to How to apply for an undergraduate degree page . To search or browse our undergraduate courses, visit our Undergraduate page . If your qualifications are not listed If your qualifications are not listed above, you may still be able to apply for entry to our courses – just get in touch with our course enquiries team via the contact details at the bottom of this page. English language requirements The English language requirements for our courses are provided on individual course pages as minimum IELTS scores. Note that if you achieve a minimum score of 40/Bien in English Language within Diploma, then this is equivalent to an IELTS score of 6.0 (with 5.5 in each component). For information about equivalent English language qualifications that are accepted by the University, please visit our English language requirements page . Applying for a course If you are interested in studying for a Master's degree (eg MA, MSc or LLM) or research programme (eg MPhil or PhD) at the University of Westminster, you will need to check that you meet our entry requirements. We have included typical entry requirements below, but these are simply a guideline. Some courses may also have specific subject or grade requirements, which will be listed on individual course pages. You will typically need to have the following: a Bachelor’s from the University of Luxembourg / Diplome d'Ingenieur Industriel with a score 12–13 For more details on the application process, visit our How to apply page Go to How to apply for a postgraduate degree page . To search or browse our postgraduate courses, visit our Postgraduate page . If your qualifications are not listed If your qualifications are not listed above, you may still be able to apply for entry to our courses – just get in touch with our course enquiries team via the contact details at the bottom of this page. English language requirements The English language requirements for our courses are provided on individual course pages as minimum IELTS scores. Note that if you achieve a minimum score of 48/Tres bien in English Language within Diploma, then this is equivalent to an IELTS score of 6.5 (with 6.0 in each component). For information about equivalent English language qualifications that are accepted by the University, please visit our English language requirements page . Online open days Join us at an online open day and get a feel for student life at the University of Westminster. You'll get a chance to: Speak to our academic staff Ask us any questions you may have about student finance and accommodation Find an online open day Events in your country At present, there are no planned events in your country. Please check back at a later date or explore our online open days or information sessions . International student blog If you have ever wondered what it’s like to study in London and at the University of Westminster, our international bloggers will be able to help. Our international students are sharing their experiences of adapting to life in the UK, making new friends for life, dealing with homesickness and fulfilling their dreams. Url: https://www.westminster.ac.uk/international/your-country/madagascar
Title: Madagascar | University of Westminster, London
Info: Studying at the University of Westminster, you'll be in the heart of London – with all the opportunities the city has to offer on your doorstep. Our students join us from over 160 nations and we boast a worldwide alumni community to join when you graduate. The University of Westminster’s Africa Media Centre promotes collaborative research on African film, media, communication and social change, and often hosts conferences and guest lectures in London. The centre organised several events last year, including the African Film and Politics Conference, African Film and Social Change, Media and Elections in Africa Conference, and Documenting Africa: Creating Fact or Fiction through the Lens. For more information on what London and the University of Westminster can offer you, have a look at our Student life pages . Entry requirements Undergraduate Postgraduate Applying for a course If you are interested in studying for a Bachelor's degree (eg a BA, BSc, BEng or LLB) at the University of Westminster, you will need to check that you meet our entry requirements. We have included typical entry requirements below, but these are simply a guideline. Some courses may also have specific subject or grade requirements, which will be listed on individual course pages. You will typically need to have one of the following qualifications: French Baccalaureat Diplôme Universitaire d'Études Scientifiques / Diplôme Universitaire de Technicien Supérieur / Diplôme Universitaire d'Études Littéraires a recognised International Foundation course from a UK institution. Entry requirements vary but we normally ask for between 60% and 65% For more details on the application process, visit our How to apply page Go to How to apply for an undergraduate degree page . To search or browse our undergraduate courses, visit our Undergraduate page . If your qualifications are not listed If your qualifications are not listed above, you may still be able to apply for entry to our courses – just get in touch with our course enquiries team via the contact details at the bottom of this page. If you find that your qualifications do not meet our entry requirements, you may want to consider applying for one of the University preparation courses offered by our partner college – see below for details. University preparation courses Our partner college, Kaplan International College London, offers a Foundation Certificate leading to entry to a broad range of our Bachelor's degrees. To find out more and apply, visit the Kaplan International College London website. English language requirements In addition to the above entry requirements, you will need to meet our English language requirements . Applying for a course If you are interested in studying for a Master's degree (eg MA, MSc or LLM) or research programme (eg MPhil or PhD) at the University of Westminster, you will need to check that you meet our entry requirements. We have included typical entry requirements below, but these are simply a guideline. Some courses may also have specific subject or grade requirements, which will be listed on individual course pages. For entry to a Master's degree that requires a UK 2:2 degree , you will typically need to have: Diplome d'Ingenieur / Diplôme d'Études Approfondies / Maîtris with a score of 12-13/20 / Assez Bien from a recognised institution in Madagascar For entry to a Master's degree that requires a UK 2:1 degree , you will typically need to have: Diplome d'Ingenieur / Diplôme d'Études Approfondies / Maîtris with a score of 14-15/20 / Bien from a recognised institution in Madagascar For entry to a Master's degree that requires a UK first class degree , you will typically need to have: Diplome d'Ingenieur / Diplôme d'Études Approfondies / Maîtris with a score of 16/20 / Très Bien from a recognised institution in Madagascar For more details on the application process, visit our How to apply page Go to How to apply for a postgraduate degree page . To search or browse our postgraduate courses, visit our Postgraduate page . If your qualifications are not listed If your qualifications are not listed above, you may still be able to apply for entry to our courses – just get in touch with our course enquiries team via the contact details at the bottom of this page. If you find that your qualifications do not meet our entry requirements, you may want to consider applying for one of the University preparation courses offered by our partner college – see below for details. University preparation courses Our partner college, Kaplan International College London, offers a Pre-Master's course leading to entry to a number of our Master's degrees. To find out more and apply, visit the Kaplan International College London website. English language requirements The English language requirements for our courses are provided on individual course pages as minimum IELTS scores. For information about equivalent English language qualifications that are accepted by the University, please visit our English language requirements page . Online open days Join us at an online open day and get a feel for student life at the University of Westminster. You'll get a chance to: Speak to our academic staff Ask us any questions you may have about student finance and accommodation Find an online open day Events in your country At present, there are no planned events in your country. Please check back at a later date or explore our online open days or information sessions . International student blog If you have ever wondered what it’s like to study in London and at the University of Westminster, our international bloggers will be able to help. Our international students are sharing their experiences of adapting to life in the UK, making new friends for life, dealing with homesickness and fulfilling their dreams. Url: https://www.westminster.ac.uk/international/your-country/malawi
Title: Malawi | University of Westminster, London
Info: Studying at the University of Westminster, you'll be in the heart of London – with all the opportunities the city has to offer on your doorstep. Our students join us from over 160 nations and we boast a worldwide alumni community to join when you graduate. The University of Westminster’s Africa Media Centre promotes collaborative research on African film, media, communication and social change, and often hosts conferences and guest lectures in London. The centre organised several events last year, including the African Film and Politics Conference, African Film and Social Change, Media and Elections in Africa Conference, and Documenting Africa: Creating Fact or Fiction through the Lens. For more information on what London and the University of Westminster can offer you, have a look at our Student life pages . Entry requirements Undergraduate Postgraduate Applying for a course If you are interested in studying for a Bachelor's degree (eg a BA, BSc, BEng or LLB) at the University of Westminster, you will need to check that you meet our entry requirements. We have included typical entry requirements below, but these are simply a guideline. Some courses may also have specific subject or grade requirements, which will be listed on individual course pages. For entry into Year 1 of Bachelor's degrees (Level 4) , you will typically need to have one of the following: University Diploma from Mzuzu University and University of Malawi a recognised International Foundation course from a UK institution. Entry requirements vary but we normally ask for between 60% and 65% For consideration for entry into Year 2 of Bachelor's degrees (Level 5) , you will typically have to have the following: Bachelor's degree from Mzuzu University and University of Malawi For more details on the application process, visit our How to apply page Go to How to apply for an undergraduate degree page . To search or browse our undergraduate courses, visit our Undergraduate page . If your qualifications are not listed If your qualifications are not listed above, you may still be able to apply for entry to our courses – just get in touch with our course enquiries team via the contact details at the bottom of this page. If you find that your qualifications do not meet our entry requirements, you may want to consider applying for one of the University preparation courses offered by our partner college – see below for details. University preparation courses Our partner college, Kaplan International College London, offers a Foundation Certificate leading to entry to a broad range of our Bachelor's degrees. To find out more and apply, visit the Kaplan International College London website. English language requirements The English language requirements for our courses are provided on individual course pages as minimum IELTS scores. For information about equivalent English language qualifications that are accepted by the University, please visit our English language requirements page . Applying for a course If you are interested in studying for a Master's degree (eg MA, MSc or LLM) or research programme (eg MPhil or PhD) at the University of Westminster, you will need to check that you meet our entry requirements. We have included typical entry requirements below, but these are simply a guideline. Some courses may also have specific subject or grade requirements, which will be listed on individual course pages. For entry to a Master's degree that requires a UK 2:2 degree , you will typically need to have: Master's degree with at least 60-69% / 4 / Pass with Credit from a recognised Malawi institution For entry to a Master's degree that requires a UK 2:1 degree , you will typically need to have: Master's degree with at least 70-74% / 5 / Pass with Distinction from a recognised Malawi institution For entry to a Master's degree that requires a UK first class degree , you will typically need to have: Master's degree with at least 85-100% / 6 / Pass with Distinction from a recognised Malawi institution For more details on the application process, visit our How to apply page Go to How to apply for a postgraduate degree page . To search or browse our postgraduate courses, visit our Postgraduate page . If your qualifications are not listed If your qualifications are not listed above, you may still be able to apply for entry to our courses – just get in touch with our course enquiries team via the contact details at the bottom of this page. If you find that your qualifications do not meet our entry requirements, you may want to consider applying for one of the University preparation courses offered by our partner college – see below for details. University preparation courses Our partner college, Kaplan International College London, offers a Pre-Master's course leading to entry to a number of our Master's degrees. To find out more and apply, visit the Kaplan International College London website. English language requirements The English language requirements for our courses are provided on individual course pages as minimum IELTS scores. For information about equivalent English language qualifications that are accepted by the University, please visit our English language requirements page . Online open days Join us at an online open day and get a feel for student life at the University of Westminster. You'll get a chance to: Speak to our academic staff Ask us any questions you may have about student finance and accommodation Find an online open day Events in your country At present, there are no planned events in your country. Please check back at a later date or explore our online open days or information sessions . Our international students are sharing their experiences of adapting to life in the UK, making new friends for life, dealing with homesickness and fulfilling their dreams. Url: https://www.westminster.ac.uk/international/your-country/malaysia
Title: Malaysia | University of Westminster, London
Info: Studying at the University of Westminster, you'll be in the heart of London – with all the opportunities the city has to offer on your doorstep. Our students join us from over 160 nations and we boast a worldwide alumni community to join when you graduate. For more information on what London and the University of Westminster can offer you, have a look at our Student life pages . Entry requirements Undergraduate Postgraduate Applying for a course If you are interested in studying for a Bachelor's degree (eg a BA, BSc, BEng or LLB) at the University of Westminster, you will need to check that you meet our entry requirements. We have included typical entry requirements below, but these are simply a guideline. Some courses may also have specific subject or grade requirements, which will be listed on individual course pages. For entry into Year 1 of Bachelor's degrees (Level 4) , you will typically need to have one of the following: Sijil Tinggi Persekolahan Malaysia (STPM) – The Malaysia Higher School Certificate with grades A-D on a subject-by-subject basis Unified Examination Certificate (UEC) Senior Middle Level with a minimum of 75% in more than two subjects Polytechnic Diploma (3 year post SPM/SPMV) Polytechnic Technician Certificate with high grades Matrikulasi (Matriculation Certificate) GPA 2.0 or above depending on subject College Diploma/Certificate (2/3 year post SPM) with high grades Tunku Abdul Rahman College Certificate (2 year post SPM) a recognised International Foundation course from a UK institution or a Chinese institution following a validated UK syllabus. Entry requirements vary but we normally ask for between 60% and 65% Successful completion of 1 year at a recognised university in Malaysia with a good grade A Levels or International Baccalaureate – check our course pages for details of these For consideration for entry into Year 2 of Bachelor's degrees (Level 5) you will typically need to have one of the following: Institut Teknologi MARA Diploma (3 year post SMP/STPM) with GPA 2.8 or above Tunku Abdul Rahman College Diploma (3 year post STPM) For more details on the application process, visit our How to apply page Go to How to apply for an undergraduate degree page . To search or browse our undergraduate courses, visit our Undergraduate page . If your qualifications are not listed If your qualifications are not listed above, you may still be able to apply for entry to our courses – just get in touch with our course enquiries team via the contact details at the bottom of this page. If you find that your qualifications do not meet our entry requirements, you may want to consider applying for one of the University preparation courses offered by our partner college – see below for details. University preparation courses Our partner college, Kaplan International College London, offers a Foundation Certificate leading to entry to a broad range of our Bachelor's degrees. To find out more and apply, visit the Kaplan International College London website. English language requirements The English language requirements for our courses are provided on individual course pages as minimum IELTS scores. For information about equivalent English language qualifications that are accepted by the University, please visit our English language requirements page . Applying for a course If you are interested in studying for a Master's degree (eg MA, MSc or LLM) or research programme (eg MPhil or PhD) at the University of Westminster, you will need to check that you meet our entry requirements. We have included typical entry requirements below, but these are simply a guideline. Some courses may also have specific subject or grade requirements, which will be listed on individual course pages. You will typically need to have the following qualification: Malaysian Bachelor's degree from a recognised institution with a minimum GPA of 2.5 for courses requiring a UK 2:2 degree, or 2.8 for those requiring a UK 2:1 degree Applicants with STPM College Diploma plus three to five years relevant work experience may also be considered on an individual basis for some Master's programmes. For more details on the application process, visit our How to apply page Go to How to apply for a postgraduate degree page . To search or browse our postgraduate courses, visit our Postgraduate page . If your qualifications are not listed If your qualifications are not listed above, you may still be able to apply for entry to our courses – just get in touch with our course enquiries team via the contact details at the bottom of this page. If you find that your qualifications do not meet our entry requirements, you may want to consider applying for one of the University preparation courses offered by our partner college – see below for details. University preparation courses Our partner college, Kaplan International College London, offers a Pre-Master's course leading to entry to a number of our Master's degrees. To find out more and apply, visit the Kaplan International College London website. English language requirements The English language requirements for our courses are provided on individual course pages as minimum IELTS scores. For information about equivalent English language qualifications that are accepted by the University, please visit our English language requirements page . Online open days Join us at an online open day and get a feel for student life at the University of Westminster. You'll get a chance to: Speak to our academic staff Ask us any questions you may have about student finance and accommodation Find an online open day Events in your country At present, there are no planned events in your country. Please check back at a later date or explore our online open days or information sessions . Overseas representatives The University of Westminster's representatives in Malaysia can help you with all stages of the admissions process. See our representatives International student blog If you have ever wondered what it’s like to study in London and at the University of Westminster, our international bloggers will be able to help. Title: Sierra Leone | University of Westminster, London
Info: Studying at the University of Westminster, you'll be in the heart of London – with all the opportunities the city has to offer on your doorstep. Our students join us from over 160 nations and we boast a worldwide alumni community to join when you graduate. For more information on what London and the University of Westminster can offer you, have a look at our Student life pages . The University of Westminster’s Africa Media Centre promotes collaborative research on African film, media, communication and social change, and often hosts conferences and guest lectures in London. The centre organised several events last year, including the African Film and Politics Conference, African Film and Social Change, Media and Elections in Africa Conference, and Documenting Africa: Creating Fact or Fiction through the Lens. Entry Requirements Undergraduate Postgraduate Applying for a course If you are interested in studying for a Bachelor's degree (eg a BA, BSc, BEng or LLB) at the University of Westminster, you will need to check that you meet our entry requirements. We have included typical entry requirements below, but these are simply a guideline. Some courses may also have specific subject or grade requirements, which will be listed on individual course pages. You will typically need to have one of the following: a recognised International Foundation course from a UK institution following a validated UK syllabus. Entry requirements vary but we normally ask for between 60% and 65% National Diploma/Ordinary Diploma Higher National Diploma/Higher Diploma For more details on the application process, visit our How to apply page Go to How to apply for an undergraduate degree page . Applying for a course If you are interested in studying for a Master's degree (eg MA, MSc or LLM) or research programme (eg MPhil or PhD) at the University of Westminster, you will need to check that you meet our entry requirements. We have included typical entry requirements below, but these are simply a guideline. Some courses may also have specific subject or grade requirements, which will be listed on individual course pages. You will typically need to have one of the following: Bachelor's degree with a score of 50-59%/B/Second Class Lower from a recognised institution in Sierra Leone. Students applying for postgraduate courses requiring a UK 2:1 degree will need 60-69%/B+/Second Class Upper, and those applying for a course requiring a UK First Class degree will need 70-100%/A/First Class Master's degree from a recognised institution in Sierra Leone For more details on the application process, visit our How to apply page Go to How to apply for a postgraduate degree page . To search or browse our postgraduate courses, visit our Postgraduate page . If your qualifications are not listed If your qualifications are not listed above, you may still be able to apply for entry to our courses – just get in touch with our course enquiries team via the contact details at the bottom of this page. If you find that your qualifications do not meet our entry requirements, you may want to consider applying for one of the University preparation courses offered by our partner college – see below for details. University preparation courses Our partner college, Kaplan International College London, offers a Pre-Master's course leading to entry to a number of our Master's degrees. To find out more and apply, visit the Kaplan International College London website. English language requirements The English language requirements for our courses are provided on individual course pages as minimum IELTS scores. For information about equivalent English language qualifications that are accepted by the University, please visit our English language requirements page . Some courses may also have specific subject or grade requirements, which will be listed on individual course pages. You will typically need to have one of the following : Bachelor's degree with at least grade C/50%/Class II, division ii. Students applying for postgraduate courses requiring a UK 2:1 degree will need B/60%/Class II, division i, and those applying for a course requiring a UK First Class degree will need A/70%/Class I. Title: Singapore | University of Westminster, London
Info: Studying at the University of Westminster, you'll be in the heart of London – with all the opportunities the city has to offer on your doorstep. Entry requirements Undergraduate Postgraduate Applying for a course If you are interested in studying for a Bachelor's degree (eg a BA, BSc, BEng or LLB) at the University of Westminster, you will need to check that you meet our entry requirements. We have included typical entry requirements below, but these are simply a guideline. Some courses may also have specific subject or grade requirements, which will be listed on individual course pages. For entry into Year 1 of Bachelor's degrees (Level 4) , you will typically need to have one of the following: Singapore/Cambridge A-Levels or the International Baccalaureate Diploma from Singapore, Ngee Ann, Nanyang and Temasek Polytechnic with good average grades in relevant subject areas Successful completion of one year at a recognised university in Singapore with a good grade A recognised International Foundation course from a UK institution or a Philippine institution following a validated UK syllabus. Entry requirements vary but we normally ask for between 60% and 65% A Levels or International Baccalaureate (see our course pages for details) To be considered for entry into Year 2 of Bachelor's degrees (Leve l 5) , you will typically need to have: Advanced Diploma with good grades (from a recognised public or private educational institution) Successful completion of a business related Singapore Advanced Diploma qualifies students for direct entry to the Global Trade and Business BA (Top Up) For more details on the application process, visit our How to apply page Go to How to apply for an undergraduate degree page . We have included typical entry requirements below, but these are simply a guideline. Some courses may also have specific subject or grade requirements, which will be listed on individual course pages. You will typically need to have one of the following: Holders of a good Bachelor's degree from the National University of Singapore, Nanyang Technical University, or universities of equivalent standing overseas, will be considered for postgraduate study Advanced Diploma with exceptional grades and sufficient relevant work experience may be considered for an appropriate taught Master's degrees For more details on the application process, visit our How to apply page Go to How to apply for a postgraduate degree page . Title: Iran | University of Westminster, London
Info: Studying at the University of Westminster, you'll be in the heart of London – with all the opportunities the city has to offer on your doorstep. Our students join us from over 160 nations and we boast a worldwide alumni community to join when you graduate. For more information on what London and the University of Westminster can offer you, have a look at our Student life pages . Watch Professor Tajalli Keshavarz (Faculty of Science and technology, Graduate Centre Coordinator) in an interview on BBC Persian where he describes his research area in microbial communication and its applications, and explains the philosophy behind his interest in science. The programme continues exploring his scientific ideas on communicating particles and his new approach to Persian poetry. In a second BBC Persian interview, Professor Keshavarz introduces his outlook on Free Will or Determinism from the scientific perspective. He refers to the need for a “Third Way”, a fresh viewpoint to this old and complex topic. He introduces the “Fluid Will” concept in a timeless an ever-changing world of particles and universes. A third talk by Professor Tajalli Keshavarz and Dr Jila Dana-Haeri takes a glance at Determinism and Free Will in Persian Mystic Poetry. Entry requirements Undergraduate Postgraduate Applying for a course If you are interested in studying for a Bachelor's degree (eg a BA, BSc, BEng or LLB) at the University of Westminster, you will need to check that you meet our entry requirements. We have included typical entry requirements below, but these are simply a guideline. Some courses may also have specific subject or grade requirements, which will be listed on individual course pages. You will typically need to have one of the following: College of Technology Diploma (2 years) (Peeshdaneshgahe) with a minimum score of 14 3 year High School Diploma ( Diplom – Metevaseth / Nameh Dabirestan, Nazari or Fani Herfei) plus Konkur (National University Entrance Examination) with a high grade Kardani associate degree with a minimum score of 14 a recognised International Foundation course from a UK institution following a validated UK syllabus. Entry requirements vary but we normally ask for between 60% and 65% A Levels or International Baccalaureate – check our course pages for details 4-year High School Diploma with a minimum score of 14 Degrees awarded by the University of Westminster are recognised by the Iranian Ministry of Education. A full list of recognised institutions can be found on the Ministry website . For more details on the application process, visit our How to apply page Go to How to apply for an undergraduate degree page . To search or browse our undergraduate courses, visit our Undergraduate page . If your qualifications are not listed If your qualifications are not listed above, you may still be able to apply for entry to our courses – just get in touch with our course enquiries team via the contact details at the bottom of this page. To find out more and apply, visit the Kaplan International College London website . For information about equivalent English language qualifications that are accepted by the University, please visit our English language requirements page . Applying for a course If you are interested in studying for a Master's degree (eg MA, MSc or LLM) or research programme (eg MPhil or PhD) at the University of Westminster, you will need to check that you meet our entry requirements. We have included typical entry requirements below, but these are simply a guideline. Some courses may also have specific subject or grade requirements, which will be listed on individual course pages. For entry to a Master's degree that requires a UK 2:2 degree , you will typically need to have: a Bachelor's degree (Licence or Karshenasi) with a minimum grade of 14.0 For entry to a Master's degree that requires a UK 2:1 degree , you will typically need to have: a Bachelor's Degree (Licence or Karshenasi) with a minimum grade of 15.5 For entry to a research (PhD) programme , you will typically need to have one of the following: a Master's degree Karshenasi Arshad/Foghe Lisance (Master’s Degree) from a recognised university in Iran Degrees awarded by the University of Westminster are recognised by the Iranian Ministry of Education. A full list of recognised institutions can be found on the Ministry website . For more details on the application process, visit our How to apply page Go to How to apply for a postgraduate degree page . To search or browse our postgraduate courses, visit our Postgraduate page . Url: https://www.westminster.ac.uk/international/your-country/laos
Title: Laos | University of Westminster, London
Info: Studying at the University of Westminster, you'll be in the heart of London – with all the opportunities the city has to offer on your doorstep. Our students join us from over 160 nations and we boast a worldwide alumni community to join when you graduate. For more information on what London and the University of Westminster can offer you, have a look at our Student life pages . Entry requirements Undergraduate Postgraduate Applying for a course If you are interested in studying for a Bachelor's degree (eg a BA, BSc, BEng or LLB) at the University of Westminster, you will need to check that you meet our entry requirements. We have included typical entry requirements below, but these are simply a guideline. Some courses may also have specific subject or grade requirements, which will be listed on individual course pages. For entry into Year 1 of Bachelor's degrees (Level 4) , you will typically need to have one of the following: a recognised International Foundation course from a UK institution or a Cambodian institution following a validated UK syllabus. Entry requirements vary but we normally ask for between 60% and 65% A levels or International Baccalaureate (see course pages for details) To be considered for entry into Year 2 of Bachelor's degrees (Leve l 5) , you will typically need to have: Higher Diploma (equivalent to BTEC Level 4) with a final GPA of at least 3.0 For more details on the application process, visit our How to apply page Go to How to apply for an undergraduate degree page . To search or browse our undergraduate courses, visit our Undergraduate page . If your qualifications are not listed If your qualifications are not listed above, you may still be able to apply for entry to our courses – just get in touch with our overseas representatives or course enquiries team via the contact details on this page. If you find that your qualifications do not meet our entry requirements, you may want to consider applying for one of the University preparation courses offered by our partner college – see below for details. University preparation courses Our partner college, Kaplan International College London, offers a Foundation Certificate leading to entry to a broad range of our Bachelor's degrees. To find out more and apply, visit the Kaplan International College London website. English language requirements The English language requirements for our courses are provided on individual course pages as minimum IELTS scores. For information about equivalent English language qualifications that are accepted by the University, please visit our English language requirements page . Applying for a course If you are interested in studying for a Master's degree (eg MA, MSc or LLM) or research programme (eg MPhil or PhD) at the University of Westminster, you will need to check that you meet our entry requirements. We have included typical entry requirements below, but these are simply a guideline. Some courses may also have specific subject or grade requirements, which will be listed on individual course pages. You will typically need to have one of the following: A master’s degree from a recognised higher education institution Students applying for graduate courses requiring a UK Lower Second Class (2:2) degree will need a master’s degree with a final GPA of 2.8 Students applying for graduate courses requiring a UK Lower Second Class (2:1) degree will need a master’s degree with a final GPA of 3.0 For more details on the application process, visit our How to apply page Go to How to apply for a postgraduate degree page . To search or browse our postgraduate courses, visit our Postgraduate page . If your qualifications are not listed If your qualifications are not listed above, you may still be able to apply for entry to our courses – just get in touch with our overseas representatives or course enquiries team via the contact details at the bottom of this page. If you find that your qualifications do not meet our entry requirements, you may want to consider applying for one of the University preparation courses offered by our partner college – see below for details. University preparation courses Our partner college, Kaplan International College London, offers a Pre-Master's course leading to entry to a number of our Master's degrees. To find out more and apply, visit the Kaplan International College London website. English language requirements The English language requirements for our courses are provided on individual course pages as minimum IELTS scores. For information about equivalent English language qualifications that are accepted by the University, please visit our English language requirements page . With a special focus on people and place, the course will encourage you to develop a deep sympathy for the needs and aspirations of the users of a space, as well as a sensitivity towards (and response to) physical and social contexts.

The emphasis of the course is on innovative design work, and on developing a caring and critical approach to the study and practice of architecture.

Graduates thrive in government, consultancy, and financial sectors as economic analysts, regulatory economists, and market analysts. WESTMINSTER STORIES Five reasons to study Accounting and Finance at Westminster Find out what makes our courses different and how will we support you to become a work-ready graduate. Read more Go to the five reasons to study accounting and finance page on the Westminster Business School Blog My year abroad in Hong Kong - An unforgettable experience We spoke to Kareem Mahfouz who recently completed a year studying abroad at Hong Kong Baptist University (HKBU). Read more Go to the My work experience hightlights page on the Westminster Business School Blog My time studying at Copenhagen Business School Ryan Dinu, a second-year Fintech with Data Analytics BSc student, attended a Summer School at Copenhagen Business School. Read more Go to the university symposium promotes diversity in finance and accounting news page Chat with our students Ask some of our current students about their experience of life at the University of Westminster. Find out more Go to the chat to our students page WHAT OUR STUDENTS SAY Matthew Bell Accounting BSc (Hons) - Regulatory analyst, SMBC Europe Ltd After the financial crisis, I wanted to understand how banks have changed and how the stricter regulations affected them. I worked in the regulatory team at SMBC, a Japanese bank. My role was to produce liquidity reports that were sent out internally and externally to regulators. It has definitely helped my career goals as I would like to go into regulatory banking after graduating which was an area I previously I knew very little about. Oreoluwa Akinyele Investment and Risk Finance MSc - 2023 I love the fact I am meeting new people with diverse cultures and personalities and because of London’s location, I get to see new places and have great experiences. I am enjoying studying Investment and Risk Finance, especially because in class I can relate the scenarios that I study in books to real-life situations. Lara Abed-Stephen Business Management (Accounting) BA Honours - 2018 Finance Analyst | IBM UK Ltd I chose to do a placement year as I believe it would help me with my future career. I also wanted to see if finance was something I wanted to pursue after I graduated. I study Accounting at Westminster and have been able to first hand see how finance and accounting works in a huge corporation like IBM. My job as Finance Analyst included revenue, cost transfers, and days sales outstanding support. This year has helped me realize my potential, and helped me figure out what career path I want to go down. dream it. believe it. achieve it. Facilities Accounting and Finance students will have access to outstanding facilities, including our Blomberg Financial Markets Suites, to gain first hand exposure to technology and data widely adopted in all leading global investment banks in the major financial centres of the world. Carousel with 5 items. Use the Previous and Next buttons to navigate, or the slide dot buttons at the end to jump to slides. Bloomberg Financial Markets Suites The purpose-built Financial Markets Suites (FMS) exclusively utilises the Bloomberg platform for the purpose of providing a state-of-the-art teaching and research resource. Social Space Our brand-new social space is a vibrant hub where you meet with friends, unwind between classes and collaborate on group projects. Lecture Theatres Our Marylebone campus has an impressive selection of modern lecture theatres equipped with state-of-the-art audio-visual equipment. Marylebone Library Our library has a range of books and resources on subjects taught at our Marylebone Campus. Students also have access to our libraries across all the campuses. Academic Engagement Librarians and Learning Developers are available on campus and via our online chat to offer advice. Study Spaces Our libraries provide designated group, individual and distanced individual study spaces. There is also a range of study spaces available across the campus, outside of the library. Url: https://www.westminster.ac.uk/architecture-interiors-and-urban-design-courses/2025-26/september/full-time/architecture-ma
Title: Architecture MA - Courses | University of Westminster, London
UK Fees: £9,700
International Fees: £15,500
Duration: 1 year
Campus: Marylebone, Central London
Course summary: The Architecture MA offers a unique opportunity for graduates interested in the intersection of architectural design, theory and research, encouraging students to develop their own positions and identities as creative practitioners and thinkers. A range of thematic and contextual concerns are offered and explored through the course using unconventional and imaginative methods of design, research and representation. These include cultural identity, architecture and society, political architecture, contested landscapes and digital design. These diverse fields of inquiry and their impact on our cities are underpinned by integrating ‘other’ voices such as post-colonialism, critical theory, feminist theory and race studies. The course promotes methodological and representational innovation, with participants using techniques such as social mapping, interactive installations, film and conceptual modelling to stimulate projects towards high-levels of spatial, material and formal resolution.

Our course also provides the opportunity to gain work experience and apply your knowledge in a health psychology setting, while considering future career plans.

International Fees: £8,750

Course summary: The English Language and Linguistics MA explores the linguistic features of English from theoretical, applied, synchronic and diachronic perspectives. Url: https://www.westminster.ac.uk/architecture-interiors-and-urban-design-courses/2025-26/september/part-time-day/architecture-ma
Title: Architecture MA - Courses | University of Westminster, London
UK Fees: £1,125
International Fees: £1,785
Duration: 2 years
Campus: Marylebone, Central London
Course summary: The Architecture MA offers a unique opportunity for graduates interested in the intersection of architectural design, theory and research, encouraging students to develop their own positions and identities as creative practitioners and thinkers. A range of thematic and contextual concerns are offered and explored through the course using unconventional and imaginative methods of design, research and representation. These include cultural identity, architecture and society, political architecture, contested landscapes and digital design. These diverse fields of inquiry and their impact on our cities are underpinned by integrating ‘other’ voices such as post-colonialism, critical theory, feminist theory and race studies. The course promotes methodological and representational innovation, with participants using techniques such as social mapping, interactive installations, film and conceptual modelling to stimulate projects towards high-levels of spatial, material and formal resolution.

International Fees: £17,000

International Fees: £17,000
Duration: 1 year
Campus: Regent, Central London

UK Fees: £8,500
International Fees: £15,000
Duration: 1 year
Campus: Regent, Central London
Course summary: Our International Communication, Liaison and Advocacy MA is a dynamic, pioneering interdisciplinary course, which meets the demand for greater professionalism in interpersonal and inter-institutional bilingual communication in an international arena. We focus on enhancing your skills as a communicator and facilitator of communication. This can be as an advocate, as a mediator, communication strategist, intermediary or communication facilitator. Grounded in the latest international communications theories and using real-life simulations, you'll learn to locate and analyse resources, pre-empt communications challenges and develop strategies to overcome obstacles to successful interaction.

Duration: 1 year
Campus: Regent, Central London
Course summary: The English Language and Linguistics MA explores the linguistic features of English from theoretical, applied, synchronic and diachronic perspectives. It will also equip you with the intellectual perspectives and scholarly skills to conduct independent research.

International Fees: £15,000
Duration: 1 year

It will also equip you with the intellectual perspectives and scholarly skills to conduct independent research.

Course summary: Global issues and challenges, such as armed conflicts, terrorism, global warming and environmental degradation, economic inequality and injustice, migration, religious and cultural discord, have gained increased prominence, as have the range of actors and stakeholders at global, national and local level engaged in diplomatic activity to address them. Negotiated solutions are increasingly in demand and so are professionals with the knowledge and skills to engage effectively in diplomatic activity in a diverse and contested world.

Url: https://www.westminster.ac.uk/study/upcoming-courses/fashion-accessories-design-ma
Title: Fashion Accessories Design MA | University of Westminster
Info: Course Summary Accessories is the fastest growing sector of the fashion design industry and the need for good accessory designers is extremely strong globally. Our Fashion Accessories Design MA addresses contemporary challenges with a focus on material innovation and cutting-edge design. Leveraging our strong industry relationships, we offer live, authentic project briefs that capitalise on our international reputation for excellence in fashion design education. This course equips graduates with professional skills and expertise in emerging technologies and innovations in textile and fashion systems, preparing them for future-focused careers in the fashion industry. Why this course? The Fashion Accessories Design MA equips students with the professional knowledge and the key technical skills needed for successful careers in the growing accessories sector of the fashion industry. Learn from experts – You'll be taught by highly experienced staff in both academia and the fashion industry, who specialise in historical and cultural research, materials and fabrication, digital specifications, drawing, sampling, and prototyping Strong connections with industry – Fashion at Westminster has close links with brands like Asprey, Mulberry, Burberry, Dior, Louis Vuitton, Marc Jacobs, Loewe, Armani and Balenciaga Westminster Menswear Archive – You'll have access to over 2,500 designer menswear items and accessories, enhancing your understanding of material properties and production techniques Outstanding design facilities – You’ll have a dedicated studio equipped with industrial sewing machines, pattern cutting tables and mannequins Who is this for? This course is designed for internationally minded, entrepreneurial graduates aiming to excel in accessory design within the global fashion industry. Graduates will be prepared for careers working on leather goods, handbags, printed accessories, and more. This course prepares students for design leadership roles, equipping them with creative strategies to support leading accessory brands in various fashion settings. Job roles include: Accessories Designer Pattern Cutter in accessories Trend Researcher Freelance creatives Find out when this course is launched Keep up with the latest information for the Fashion Accessories Design MA. Register your interest and be the first to know when this course becomes available. Register now Why Westminster? Our Fashion Accessories Design MA draws on the success of our Fashion courses at undergraduate and postgraduate level. Our courses are widely recognised for their professional practice, global industry links and their impact on the fashion industry. Industry-ready This course is designed with fashion industry requirements at the forefront and underpinned by our renowned Westminster Menswear Archive. Transferable skills This course will equip you with a range of highly marketable and hands-on skills pertaining to fashion accessories and circularity. Stand out from the crowd Qualified fashion accessories designers are currently in high demand in the job market. Supporting you Our Student Hub is where you’ll find out about the services and support we offer, helping you get the best out of your time with us. Study support — workshops, 1-2-1 support and online resources to help improve your academic and research skills Personal tutors — support you in fulfilling your academic and personal potential Student advice team — provide specialist advice on a range of issues including funding, benefits and visas Extra-curricular activities — volunteering opportunities, sports and fitness activities, student events and more Visit our student hub Carousel with 7 items. Use the Previous and Next buttons to navigate, or the slide dot buttons at the end to jump to slides. Our design students have their own dedicated studio to work in, equipped with individual design spaces. Each of our design studios are equipped with industrial sewing machines, pattern cutting tables and mannequins that replicate the environment of real-world design studios. Each of our design studios are equipped with industrial sewing machines, pattern cutting tables and mannequins that replicate the environment of real-world design studios. It features professional standard hardware and software, as well as collaborative and private workspaces. Our Fashion students benefit from our industry-standard suite of photography equipment, studios, darkrooms, print and finishing facilities, enabling them to bring their fashion photography projects to life. Url: https://www.westminster.ac.uk/study/upcoming-courses/fashion-manufacturing-ma
Title: Fashion Manufacturing MA | University of Westminster
Info: Course Summary Our Fashion Manufacturing MA tackles current industry challenges and skills shortages by focusing on apparel production, systems, sourcing, and manufacturing processes. This research-driven and industry-informed course is tailored to the evolving needs of fashion manufacturing, including design, product development, and innovative processes. This course explores new production models, integrates cutting-edge processes, and prepares students for leadership roles in fashion and textiles. The Fashion Manufacturing MA focuses on practical industry engagement and is developed in collaboration with UK Fashion and Textiles Organisation ( UKFT), with course content reflecting their insights and guidance, ensuring it addresses the needs and skill gaps of the industry. Why this course? The Fashion Manufacturing MA equips graduates with the essential skills to thrive in the digital fashion industry. Integrating expert-led modules and global insights, this course fosters employability, enterprise, and global fluency, bridging fashion design, business, and production. Industry-Relevant Skills : Acquire practical skills in emerging technologies and innovations for fashion manufacturing Enhanced Employability: Develop advanced expertise in fashion manufacturing technology and gain hands-on knowledge of the latest techniques to boost career prospects and meet industry needs Expert-Led: Learn from our experienced specialists from both academia and industry and benefit from our UKFT partnership State-of-the-Art Resources: Access cutting-edge software and tools, including CLO 3D Practical Learning: Engage in problem-solving and critical thinking to challenge existing practices and focus on real-world applications. Who is this for? The Fashion Manufacturing MA is ideal for students eager to innovate and challenge traditional fashion manufacturing systems. It’s designed for individuals from various fashion disciplines who are passionate about fashion production and manufacturing. This course prepares graduates to understand clothing production and shape the future of the industry, equipping them with international, entrepreneurial skills for successful careers and roles such as: Fashion Production Manager Sourcing Manager Product Development Manager Studio Manager Find out when this course is launched Keep up with the latest information for the Fashion Manufacturing MA. Register your interest and be the first to know when this course becomes available. Register now Why Westminster? Our Fashion Manufacturing MA draws on the success of our Fashion courses at undergraduate and postgraduate level. Our courses are widely recognised for their professional practice, global industry links and their impact on the fashion industry. Industry-ready This course is designed with fashion industry manufacturing requirements at the forefront. Transferable skills This course will equip you with a range of highly marketable and hands-on skills pertaining to fashion manufacturing. Url: https://www.westminster.ac.uk/study/upcoming-courses/fashion-sustainability-ma
Title: Fashion Sustainability MA | University of Westminster
Info: Course Summary The Fashion Sustainability MA tackles modern sustainability challenges in fashion, emphasising innovation in materials, systems and sustainable practices such as design, sourcing, and manufacturing. This research-informed course has a specific focus on the fashion systems, waste management, and circularity through design networks and processes. With a strong industry focus, it equips entrepreneurial graduates with the skills to build transformative relationships among suppliers, retailers, and consumers and successful careers within the field of sustainability in the fashion industry. Why this course? Addressing the pressing issues of overconsumption and its impact on global production and distribution, this course explores innovative processes, new systems, and business models to push the boundaries of traditional fashion practices. Expert-led: You’ll learn from leading experts in academia and industry, focusing on zero waste and sustainable systems Choose your path: Select individual areas of focus, ensuring your research has real-world applications benefiting society, culture, and ecology Practical learning: Through hands-on projects and a critical examination of the fashion system, you’ll be prepared to tackle the climate crisis and lead responsible, innovative practices in fashion Future-ready skills: As investment in sustainable fashion becomes crucial for the industry's future, this course integrates sustainability holistically, linking modules, international expertise, and enterprise Who is this for? The Fashion Sustainability MA is designed for individuals ready to challenge fashion's unsustainable footprint through critical thinking and problem-solving. This innovative course prepares students for responsible leadership roles, empowering them to transform the industry with creative strategies that promote sustainability, social equity, and ethical practices. Ideal candidates include fashion graduates looking to expand their skills in sustainability and industry professionals seeking to up-skill or transition into sustainable fashion practices. Job roles include: Fashion Sustainability Manager Sustainable Product Development Manager Environmental Fashion Analyst Fashion Supply Chain Circularity & Materials Manager Design Manager Find out when this course is launched Keep up with the latest information for the Fashion Sustainability MA. Url: https://www.westminster.ac.uk/events/faiz-amn-mela-faiz-peace-festival
Title: Faiz Am'n Mela (Faiz Peace Festival) | University of Westminster
Info: Faiz Am'n Mela (Faiz Peace Festival) is the annual event Faiz Cultural Foundation - UK organises to promote equality, peace and progressive discourse through dialogue, art, literature and culture. This year we will be celebrating life and work of three iconic progressive poets of South Asia, Faiz Ahmad Faiz, Sheikh Ayaz and Kaifi Azmi. This year’s line-up includes Sardar Shah, Senator Hasil Bazinjo, Iftikhar Arif, Dr Aysha Siddiqa and Atif Tauqeer. Renowned poets from UK, Europe, USA, Canada and Pakistan will recite their poetry to pay tribute to Kaifi Azmi. Students of the University of Westminster will perform spoken word poetry on the themes of race and gender. Eminent Ghazal Singer Anup Jalota and Nirmala Maghani will be singing Faiz’s poetry. University of Westminster G.03 Ground Floor 4–12 Little Titchfield Street London W1W 7BY For more information please call 07903 706884. This is a not-for-profit event. Tickets are non refundable, Rights of admission are reserved.

Url: https://www.westminster.ac.uk/events/book-launch-reimagining-pakistan-in-the-twenty-first-century
Title: Book Launch: Reimagining Pakistan in the Twenty First Century | University of Westminster
Info: This event is a discussion around a recently published edited collection of articles on various lingering issues pertaining to Pakistan at a local and global level. The issues include analysis of politics, economics, foreign policy, human rights, religious fundamentalism as well as new approaches to development, feminism, energy and environment that may provide solutions to urgent problems. The book is a collection of 22 essays by intellectuals and experts in varied fields from Pakistan writing on five themes: Identity, Religion and Radicalisation; Develoment, Reform and Governance; Rights, Repression and Resistance; Sex, Gender and Emancipation; Conflict, Diplomacy and Foreign Policy. Each essay is crucial in understanding the contemporary challenges facing Pakistan and providing the tools for imagining a solution to the issues discussed. The scholars experiment with diverse ideas and theories while illuminating the path forward for democratic development, social progress and economic stability in the region. The book aims to centre marginalized voices from Pakistan to prioritise indigenous research and solutions. There will be a short panel discussion with: The panel discussion will be followed by an open conversation with the audience. The book launch event offers a unique opportunity for scholars working on South Asia and those looking to grasp a wider understanding of postcolonial nation states while focusing on multiple dimensions to engage directly with the author and academic experts on South Asia. Bilal Zahoor is the founder and Editorial Director of Folio Books, a Lahore-based independent publishing house. He studied chemical engineering from University of Engineering and Technology, Lahore, but did not let his academic training obstruct his passion for establishing an independent publishing platform in Pakistan. Zahoor aspires to contribute to a more socially just world by publishing works bucking the neoliberal trends and authoritarian tendencies. Rethinking Pakistan is his debut edited volume. Dr Ayesha Siddiqa is a research associate at the School for Oriental and African Studies (SOAS), University of London. She is a Ph.D. in War Studies from King’s College, London and an author of two books on Pakistan’s military including internationally acclaimed Military, Inc.: Inside Pakistan's Military Economy (Pluto Press, 2007). She has also contributed to 12 edited volumes. Her research expertise lies in military decision-making, defence economics, civil-military relations and militancy and extremism in South Asia and the Middle East. Siddiqa is the inaugural Pakistan fellow at the Woodrow Wilson International Centre for Scholars, a Ford fellow at BICC, Germany, a senior fellow at Sandia National Laboratories and Charles Wallace fellow at St. Antony’s College, Oxford. She has taught at various universities in Pakistan and the US. Victoria Schofield is an historian and commentator on international affairs, with specialist knowledge and love of South Asia, having travelled widely in India, Pakistan and Afghanistan. She is acknowledged as one of the leading international experts on the disputed region of Jammu and Kashmir and has given lectures on the subject in India, Pakistan, the United States, Europe and Australia as well as writing numerous articles on the subject. Her books include the widely-acclaimed Kashmir in the Crossfire (1996), Kashmir in Conflict: India, Pakistan and the Unending War (2000, 2002, 2010) and Afghan Frontier: at the Crossroads of Conflict (2003, 2010). Schofield is a frequent contributor to BBC World TV, BBC World Service and other news outlets including Al Jazeera. Professor Dibyesh Anand is the Head of the School of Social Sciences at the University of Westminster. He is the author of monographs "Geopolitical Exotica: Tibet in Western Imagination” and “Hindu Nationalism in India and the Politics of Fear” and has spoken about and published on varied topics including Tibet, China-India border dispute, Hindu nationalism and Islamophobia in India, and the colonial occupation in Kashmir. Rashed Rahman is a veteran journalist from Pakistan who has held senior editorial positions in a number of daily newspapers. His last assignment was Editor, Daily Times. Westminster Forum,

Url: https://www.westminster.ac.uk/events/what-it-takes-to-work-in-mental-health-and-wellbeing
Title: What It Takes To Work In Mental Health And Wellbeing | University of Westminster
Info: Join a panel of alumnae as they give insight into working within mental health and wellbeing, and share their own personal experiences of coping with and supporting others with their mental health and wellbeing. The panel of practitioners will speak about their journeys from Westminster into working in mental health and wellbeing, and they will cover topics such as: It goes without saying that mental health and wellbeing are extremely important to all, so come along if you are interested in either working in the sectors, or for advice and insight into how best to support yourself and others. There will be time to ask the panel questions both during the Q&A and informally after the event with refreshments and networking. Elif is currently working as a Mental Health Specialist at Caritas Anchor House, a homelessness charity. She supports individuals who present with complex needs, and dual diagnosis transition from homelessness to independent living. Elif has previously worked in primary and secondary care mental health NHS services, which also involved forming an innovative pilot project for psychology in a health service in Hertfordshire. Her core interests include: psychosis, personality disorders and promoting better physical health and mental health in excluded populations e.g. the homeless. Anastasia is a passionate mental health advocate, following her own experiences with depression and anxiety, which started when she was 17. Currently, Anastasia is Wellbeing Lead at the Bank of England, a member of the Commission for Equality in Mental Health, and a Steering Committee member of the Thriving from the Start Network – a mental health network for those early on in their careers, or about to finish their studies. Through her work, Anastasia is keen to decrease stigma around mental health conditions in the workplace and beyond. Azmara is a BABCP accredited Cognitive Behavioural Psychotherapist and the BME lead at a primary care psychology service in London. She completed her postgraduate diploma at Royal Holloway University of London and she graduated from Westminster in 2014. Azmara is passionate about working in the field of trauma, following her prolonged experience in working with trauma survivors. Having witnessed stigma and challenges in her community and country of origin, she is keen to work with ethnic communities and raise mental health awareness. Chloé is what we call a ‘modern adventurer’! She is the Founder of the Cool Girls Club, a special membership that connects women across the world, helps them find their purpose and implement it in their lives. Thanks to a series of monthly webinars, local workshops and private sessions, Chloé not only empowers women, she also keeps them accountable for taking action towards their dreams. She has hosted workshops in India, Spain and the UK, in French, English and Spanish, and has helped clients from a wide range of cultural backgrounds to get unstuck. Chloé also freelances for the International Maritime Organization, United Nations in London, and she is an accredited life coach and freelance translator/interpreter. This event is free, but you must register your place in advance. Portland Hall, 4-12 Little Titchfield Street, London, W1W 7BY Together with AccessAble, we have created online

Title: What It Takes To Work In Mental Health And Wellbeing | University of Westminster
Info: Join a panel of alumnae as they give insight into working within the mental health sector, and share their own personal experiences of coping with and supporting others with their wellbeing. Elif Huseyin, MBPsS, Mental Health Specialist, Caritas Anchor House (BSc Hons Psychology, 2013). She supports individuals who present with complex needs, and dual diagnosis transition from homelessness to independent living. Through her work, Anastasia is keen to decrease stigma around mental health conditions in the workplace and beyond. She completed her postgraduate diploma at Royal Holloway University of London and she graduated from Westminster in 2014. Azmara is passionate about working in the field of trauma, following her prolonged experience in working with trauma survivors. She is the Founder of the Cool Girls Club, a special membership that connects women across the world, helps them find their purpose and implement it in their lives. Thanks to a series of monthly webinars, local workshops and private sessions, Chloé not only empowers women, she also keeps them accountable for taking action towards their dreams. She has hosted workshops in India, Spain and the UK, in French, English and Spanish, and has helped clients from a wide range of cultural backgrounds to get unstuck. Chloé also freelances for the International Maritime Organization, United Nations in London, and she is an accredited life coach and freelance translator/interpreter.

Url: https://www.westminster.ac.uk/events/the-current-crisis-in-nuclear-arms-control-law
Title: The Current Crisis in Nuclear Arms Control Law | University of Westminster
Info: Professor Daniel H. Joyner (University of Alabama) Professor Marco Roscini (University of Westminster) Organised by International Law at Westminster (ILaW) in co-operation with ILSA Westminster Chapter. There is a crisis in modern nuclear arms control law. With the demise of the 1987 INF and the uncertainty surrounding extension of the 2010 New START treaty, there is a real danger that, as of 6 February 2021, there will be no bilaterally agreed international legal limits on either the U.S. or Russia’s stockpiling and fielding of nuclear weapons and delivery systems. In this lecture, Professor Joyner will discuss and contextualize this crisis, consider its implications, and explain how the recently adopted Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons fits into it. The Boardroom London W1B 2HW

Url: https://www.westminster.ac.uk/current-students/events/london-indie-press-book-fair
